Linguistic analysis: The expert may have analyzed the language used in the claim to determine if it matches the typical patterns and vocabulary used by individuals who have been to the Middle East. They might have looked for specific linguistic markers or cultural references that would indicate familiarity with the region.
Background investigation: The expert may have conducted a thorough background investigation on the individuals involved in the claim. This could include checking their travel history, interviewing their acquaintances or family members, and examining any available evidence that could support or refute their claim of never having been to the Middle East.
Expert opinion: The expert may have consulted with other experts or professionals in the field to gather their opinions and insights on the claim. This could involve reaching out to individuals with knowledge of the Middle East or experts in counterterrorism who could provide valuable insights into the likelihood of the claim being true.
Corroborating evidence: The expert may have sought out any available evidence that could corroborate or contradict the claim. This could include surveillance footage, travel records, witness testimonies, or any other form of evidence that could support or challenge the authenticity of the claim.
